newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures finish mixed, pound sags. [CORRECTED 23:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures finish mixed, pound sags. [CORRECTED 23:00 GMT]

text.p: IMM currency futures ended pit trading mixed, with the pound taking a late tumble to the minus side.

Sterling slumped hard during the final half-hour, slapped down from lofty morning heights after Bank of England Governor Eddie George said during a visit to Lisbon that the speed of sterling's rise since autumn suggested the rise might not persist.
The comment sent March sterling futures skidding by some $0.0100 (Corrects from $0.000100) to the day's low of $1.6460 from its perch near $1.6562, just shy of day's peak, minutes earlier.
But floor brokers said even that big swing, which briefly drew power from sell stops, occurred on relatively skimpy volume, which typically dries up after Europe closes.

"Actually, it (volume) wasn't as heavy as it should have been," said one floor broker, noting that the price boards showed estimated volume of roughly 15,000 sterling, 32,000 yen, 40,000 Swiss francs and 30,000 marks for Wednesday.
Brokers looked ahead to Thursday's November U.S. consumer price index, expected to rise 0.3 percent overall and gain 0.2 percent excluding food and energy.
But the retail-level inflation figures might need to stray far from estimates to provoke much response, especially after the muted reaction to Wednesday's tame producer price index.
Instead, they expected attention could remain riveted -- at least temporarily -- on the U.S. stock and bond markets, both of which slumped on Wednesday and lifted currencies.
But brokers voiced differing opinions about whether the dollar's recent rise will resume.
One broker said the unit appeared poised on the cusp of a move lower especially if it breaches some key technical levels and makes "weak" dollar longs flock for the exits at yearend.
Indeed, March Swiss francs briefly shot higher through resistance near $0.7690 when U.S. stocks opened sharply lower.
Currencies rose as U.S. Treasuries slid after a Wall Street Journal article said traders are worried Japanese institutions may slow their purchases of U.S. Treasuries.

Currencies also fretted about another WSJ article that said a Smith Barney survey shows that as many as 40 percent of mutual-fund holders would sell some or all of their holdings if the stock market fell 15 percent in a short period.
The Australian dollar fell after a surprise 50-basis-point rate cut by the Australian central bank.

At settlement, March yen rose $0.000029 to $0.008968, marks rose $0.0063 to $0.6540, Swiss franc jumped $0.0090 to $0.7699, Sterling eased $0.0008 to $1.6480, Canadian dollar lost $0.0015 to $0.7393, Australian dollar dropped $0.0105 to $0.7892, and the Mexican peso fell $0.000575 to $0.120075. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750/E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com))
